Because of web browser variability, all hyphens have been typed on the U.S. keyboard.
Dashes have been rendered as a variable number of hyphens to give a more exact rendering of their length.

Writing in other hands appearing on these manuscripts has been indicated as such, the content recorded in brackets.
& has been used for the ampersand sign.

All other characters, those with accents, non-breaking spaces, etc., have been encoded in HTML entity decimals.

div.head:
3489. Robert Southey to [Richard Heber] [29 May 1820] Endorsement: Southey
MS: Bodleian Library, MS Eng. Lett. d. 215. ALS; 2p.
Unpublished.
Dating note: Dated by the content, which indicates that this was written on Monday 29 May.
div.p: I received your first communication when I was on the point of setting out for Cambridge; & as you desired an answer by the 2d I took time for deliberation & advice. Upon due consideration it appears to me that I ought not to decline the proffered honour.The University of Oxford wished to confer an honorary Doctorate of Civil Law upon Southey. I would not willingly be thought <supposed> to undervalue such things; still less should I like to be thought insensible of an act of kindness. You will believe me when I say that Alma Mater in thus recognizing a truant sonSouthey had been a student at Balliol College, Oxford, 1792–1794, but had left without taking a degree. will gives me a pleasure greater both in greater pleasure than the honour itself under other circumstances could possibly have occasioned.
Have the goodness to inform me on what day I should be at Oxford.The ceremony took place in the University’s Sheldonian Theatre on 14 June 1820.
